meanings.definition: A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
meanings.sent1: The explorers struggled to cross the mire without getting their boots wet.
meanings.sent2: The farmer's cows grazed near the mire, enjoying the lush grass.
meanings.sent3: The children pretended the mire was a magical swamp filled with hidden treasures.
meanings.sent4: The mire of paperwork on his desk seemed never-ending.
meanings.sent5: The mire was so thick that even the strongest horses couldn't pass through.

meanings.definition: To cause to become stuck in mud.
meanings.sent1: The heavy rain mired the car in the muddy road.
meanings.sent2: She accidentally mired her shoes in the wet clay while walking in the park.
meanings.sent3: The clumsy puppy mired itself in the mud while trying to chase a squirrel.
meanings.sent4: His careless actions mired the project in delays and setbacks.
meanings.sent5: The construction truck got mired in the soft ground and needed a tow.

meanings.definition: To involve or entangle in difficulties.
meanings.sent1: The new policy change mired the company in confusion and complaints.
meanings.sent2: She didn't want to mire herself in unnecessary drama, so she stayed out of the argument.
meanings.sent3: The detective's attempt to solve the case only seemed to mire him deeper in mysteries.
meanings.sent4: The political scandal mired the candidate's reputation in controversy.
meanings.sent5: The decision to cut costs ended up miring the company in legal troubles.
